codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_PresentationFormCode"                                                codeListValue="mapDigital">mapDigital</gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode>                </gmd:presentationForm>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>The Bathymetry of North America map layer shows depth ranges using colors. The image was derived from the National Geophysical Data Center's ETOPO2 elevation data, which is an elevation database gridded at 2-minute resolution, containing elevation and bathymetry for the world. The image was produced from the October 2001 data set.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The bathymetry image was developed to portray ocean depths around North America. This image is intended for visual purposes only. The original ETOPO2 data must be used for conducting analysis and determining specific bathymetric values.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode"                                  codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>          </gmd:status>          <gmd:pointOfContact>             <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                <gmd:individualName>                   <gco:CharacterString>L.   <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>The ETOPO2 dataset was downloaded from the National Geophysical Data Center web site using their GEODAS Grid Translator Design-a-Grid interface. This interface allows a user to create custom grids. Users can access the web interface at http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/gdas/gd_designagrid.html. The following grid parameters were used: >Grid Database: ETOPO2 2-minute Global Relief >Latitude/Longitude Area Bounds: 90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'N to 90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'S, 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'W to 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'E >Grid Cell Size: 2 minutes >Grid Cell Value Parameters: 2-byte integers, whole meters >Grid Format: ASCII raster format, Arc header The downloaded grid was converted to an ArcInfo grid using the ArcToolbox import to raster interface. ArcToolbox was also used to define the initial coordinate system as Geographic (Lat/Lon) with units in decimal degrees, and the datum as WGS 1984. East and west grids were derived from the main grid using the ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP. The east grid coverage was from 150 degrees to 180 degrees longitude and 0 degrees to 90 degrees latitude. The west grid coverage was from 0 degrees to -180 degrees longitude and 0 degrees to 90 degrees latitude. The ArcInfo command GRIDSHIFT was used to shift each grid 40 degrees east, moving all data into the Western hemisphere. This data processing step was necessary due to the inability of ArcInfo to project raster data across the 180-degree longitude line. The ArcInfo Grid command MERGE was used to combine the two grids into one grid. This grid was projected into the Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection, centered on 100 degrees West, 45 degrees North. The .prj file used in the Arc PROJECT command contained these parameters: > INPUT > PROJECTION GEOGRAPHIC > UNITS DD > PARAMETERS > OUTPUT > PROJECTION LAMBERT_AZIMUTHAL > UNITS METERS > XSHIFT 0.0 > YSHIFT 0.0 > PARAMETERS > 0.0 > -60 0 0 > 45 0 0 > 0.0 > 0.0 > END > Using a center of longitude of 60 degrees West in the projection parameters creates an actual center of 100 degrees West due to the grid shift of 40 degrees. After projecting the data, the ArcInfo command PROJECTDEFINE was used to reset the central meridian to 100 degrees West. The ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP was used to clip the grid to match the dimensions used for National Atlas of the United States data. The bathymetric image was created by converting the depths from meters to feet, classifying the data into depth ranges, and then assigning an RGB color to each range, as shown below. The file was converted to TIFF format using the command GRIDIMAGE. >Depth Range Index Red Green Blue >From To >-28300 -16000 1 53 146 214 >-15999 -12000 2 87 159 220 >-11999 -9000 3 124 180 231 >-8999 -6000 4 146 194 237 >-5999 -3000 5 170 212 243 >-2999 -1500 6 186 219 247 >-1499 -750 7 200 228 251 >-749 20320 8 216 236 252 The lightest color tint (index 8) extends across the land area.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>2005-04-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:source xlink:href="#NGDC - ETOPO2"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:source>
